elements.content: By using a new resorcin[4]arene-based tetracarboxylate, three functional coordination polymers (CPs)namely, [(CH3)2NH2][Cd2NaL(HCOO)2(HCOOH)(H2O)]·H2O (1), [(CH3)2NH2]2[CdL]·CH3OH·4H2O (2), and [(CH3)2NH2][Zn2Na3L2(H2O)2]·H2O (3)have been synthesized under solvothermal conditions (H4L = 2,8,14,20-tetra-pentyl-4,10,16,22-tetrakis((4-carboxybenzyl)oxy)-6,12,18,24-tetra-methoxy-resorcin[4]arene and DMF = N,N′-dimethylformamide). The structures of 1–3 have been confirmed by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses and further physically characterized. In 1, L and HCOO– link Cd(II) and Na(I) ions to yield an unusual three-dimensional (3D) 4-connected heterometallic framework with (42·64)(4·83·10·12) topology. In 2, L anions link Cd(II) ions to give a 3D binodal 4-connected framework with (42·63·8)2 topology. In 3, adjacent dodecanuclear heterometallic clusters are joined together by L anions, yielding a two-dimensional (2D) (3,8)-connected (3·42)(34·46·56·68·73·8) network. Most strikingly, CPs 1 and 2 display unusual metal-ion exchange characters. CP 2 shows remarkable reversible adsoption of I2 molecules. In addition, CPs 1–3 can selectively adsorb organic dyes and exhibit highly luminescent sensing properties for small molecules.

The structures of 1-3 have been confirmed by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses and further physically characterized. In 1, L and HCOO- link Cd(II) and Na(I) ions to yield an unusual three-dimensional (3D) 4-connected heterometallic framework with (42⋅64)(4⋅83⋅10⋅12) topology. In 2, L anions link Cd(II) ions to give a 3D binodal 4-connected framework with (42⋅63⋅8)2 topology. In 3, adjacent dodecanuclear heterometallic clusters are joined together by L anions, yielding a two-dimensional (2D) (3,8)-connected (3⋅42)(34⋅46⋅56⋅68⋅73⋅8) network. Most strikingly, CPs 1 and 2 display unusual metal-ion exchange characters. CP 2 shows remarkable reversible adsoption of I2 molecules. In addition, CPs 1-3 can selectively adsorb organic dyes and exhibit highly luminescent sensing properties for small molecules.

elements.content: By using a new resorcin[4]arene-based tetracarboxylate, three coordination polymers were hydrothermally synthesized, where these compounds demonstrate remarkable metal-ion exchange, small-molecule sensing, selective dye adsorption, and reversible iodine uptake.

elements.content: In recent years, the design and synthesis of coordination polymers (CPs) have received much attention from chemists, because of their charming structures and potential applications in separation, adsorption, ion exchange, catalysis, luminescence, etc. Thus far, a large quantity of CPs has been achieved via the reaction of organic ligands with metal ions. Generally, through careful selection of organic ligands and metals, the expected CPs could be rationally synthesized, to some extent. However, it is still a great challenge to obtain target CPs with multifunctions. In this regard, CPs constructed by resorcinarene-based ligands represent an attractive area of research, because of their fascinating framework structures, as well as widespread applications in molecular recognition, chemical sensors, catalysts, etc. The resorcinarenes substituted on body and/or rims with a large variety of substituents make them very versatile ligands. In the case of resorcin[4]arenes, their upper and lower rims could be modified, which greatly enriched the structure diversities of their CPs, because of their diverse coordination modes. Nevertheless, only very limited CPs constructed by resorcin[4]arene-based ligands have been reported so far. Particularly, the development on their applications in post-synthetic modification (PSM), selective adsorption of pollutants, organic molecule sensing, etc. is greatly lacking.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In recent years, the design and synthesis of coordination polymers (CPs) have received much attention from chemists, because of their charming structures and potential applications in separation, adsorption, ion exchange, catalysis, luminescence, etc. Thus far, a large quantity of CPs has been achieved via the reaction of organic ligands with metal ions. Generally, through careful selection of organic ligands and metals, the expected CPs could be rationally synthesized, to some extent. However, it is still a great challenge to obtain target CPs with multifunctions. In this regard, CPs constructed by resorcinarene-based ligands represent an attractive area of research, because of their fascinating framework structures, as well as widespread applications in molecular recognition, chemical sensors, catalysts, etc. The resorcinarenes substituted on body and/or rims with a large variety of substituents make them very versatile ligands. In the case of resorcin[4]arenes, their upper and lower rims could be modified, which greatly enriched the structure diversities of their CPs, because of their diverse coordination modes. Nevertheless, only very limited CPs constructed by resorcin[4]arene-based ligands have been reported so far. Particularly, the development on their applications in post-synthetic modification (PSM), selective adsorption of pollutants, organic molecule sensing, etc. is greatly lacking.

elements.content: Very recently, much effort has been devoted to post-synthetic modification (PSM) of CPs, which is a powerful and versatile method for producing novel materials. On one hand, PSM could easily transform the physical and chemical properties of the CPs frameworks. On the other hand, a CP that is not obtained by conventionally synthetic method could be occasionally achieved through the PSM approach. In this regard, metal-ion exchange as one effective method of the PSMs has been successfully utilized to yield functional CPs. However, it is difficult to keep the crystalline or intergrity of the framework during the process of metal-ion exchange. Thus, only limited examples that CPs have been successfully modified through metal-ion exchange processes, retaining their crystalline or framework structures, have been known.

In this regard, metal-ion exchange as one effective method of the PSMs has been successfully utilized to yield functional CPs. However, it is difficult to keep the crystalline or intergrity of the framework during the process of metal-ion exchange. Thus, only limited examples that CPs have been successfully modified through metal-ion exchange processes, retaining their crystalline or framework structures, have been known.

elements.content: On the other hand, the development of new materials with efficient adsorption of a variety of chemical pollutants, including toxic metals, organic dyes, iodine, etc., is of great significance, from the viewpoint of the environment. In this context, CPs, as an emerging class of inorganic–organic hybrid materials, are excellent candidates for removing such chemical pollutants through adsorption. Compared with conventional adsorbents such as activated carbon, zeolite, resin, and membrane, the main advantages of CPs lie in their tunable structures as well as especially structural characters. Although the applications of CPs in pollutant trapping have been investigated up to now, CPs with selective and versatile sorption capacities of organic dyes are still rarely observed.

Although the applications of CPs in pollutant trapping have been investigated up to now, CPs with selective and versatile sorption capacities of organic dyes are still rarely observed.

elements.content: Based on above consideration, we synthesized a new resorcin[4]arene-functionalized tetracarboxylate: 2,8,14,20-tetra-pentyl-4,10,16,22- -tetrakis((4-carboxybenzyl)oxy)-6,12,18,24-tetra-methoxy-resorcin[4]arene (H4L) (see Scheme ). For the H4L ligand, the flexibility of the −O–CH2– spacer makes four benzoic acid arms coordinate with metal atoms freely in versatile coordination fashions. In this work, three new CPsnamely, [(CH3)2NH2][Cd2NaL(HCOO)2(HCOOH)(H2O)]·H2O (1), [(CH3)2NH2]2[CdL]·CH3OH·4H2O (2), and [(CH3)2NH2][Zn2Na3L2(H2O)2]·H2O (3)have been synthesized using the new resorcin[4]arene-based tetracarboxylate H4L. Remarkably, compounds 1 and 2 exhibit metal-ion exchange properties while retaining their framework structures. Compounds 1–3 can highly selectively adsorb Methylene Blue (MB) in DMF solution, and compound 2 shows unusual reversible adsorption of I2 molecules. Moreover, solid-state luminescent properties of 1–3 were detected, and further investigation on their sensing organic molecules was also demonstrated.

elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

All chemical reagents used in the experiment were commercially available. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were recorded on a Mattson Alpha Centauri spectrometer. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were measured on a Rigaku Model Dmax 2000 X-ray diffractometer with graphite monochromatized Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.154 nm). The C, H, and N elemental analyses were performed on a Perkin-Elmer Model 240C elemental analyzer. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) measurements were determined on a Perkin-Elmer Model TG-7 analyzer. Inductively coupled plasma (ICP) analyses were conducted on a Leeman Laboratories Prodigy inductively coupled plasma-optical atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES) system. The emission spectra were collected with a FLSP920 Edinburgh fluorescence spectrometer at room temperature. Diffuse reflectivity spectra were recorded on a finely ground sample with a Cary 500 spectrophotometer. All UV/vis spectra were tested by a Cary TU-1900 double-beam UV-vis spectrophotometer.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray data of 1–3 were collected at 293 K on a Oxford Diffraction Model Gemini R Ultra diffractometer, using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Absorption corrections were performed using a multiscan method. The structures were solved by Direct Method and refined by full-matrix least-squares techniques using SHELXL-97 within WINGX, and all non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. Hydrogen atoms attached to C atoms were refined by a riding model with d(C–H) = 0.93 Å, U iso = 1.2 U eq(C) for aromatic and d(C–H) = 0.97 Å, U iso = 1.5 U eq(C) for CH2. Hydrogen atoms of water molecules, (CH3)2NH2 + cations, and some disordered C atoms were not located from the difference Fourier maps. A summary of crystallographic data and structure refinements for 1–3 are provided in Table . Selected bond lengths and angles for 1–3 are given in .

Synthesis of Precursor 2,8,14,20-Tetra-pentyl-4,10,16,22-tetra- -hydroxy-6,12,18,24-tetra-methoxy-resorcin[4]arene (L1)

A mixture of 3-methoxyphenol (9.93 g, 80 mmol), hexaaldehyde (8.01 g, 80 mmol), and dichloromethane (200 mL) was stirred at ice bath for 0.5 h with the dropwise addition of BF3⋅OEt2 (22.7 g, 160 mmol). The reaction system was warmed to room temperature and stirred overnight. The product then was washed using water and NaOH (1 mol L-1). After drying (MgSO4) and evaporation of the solvent, the crude product was crystallized from CH2Cl2/petroleum ether and then white crystals were obtained (yield = 85%).

elements.content: A mixture of L1 (2.472 g, 3 mmol), methyl 4-(bromomethyl)benzoate (2.748 g, 12 mmol), anhydrous K2CO3 (8.28 g, 60 mmol), KI (0.1992 g, 1.2 mmol) and CH3CN (100 mL) was heated in a water bath for 12 h. Most of the solvent then was removed in the water bath. After that, tetrahydrofuran (150 mL), water (20 mL), and sodium hydroxide (0.96 g, 24 mmol) were put in the isolated products and refluxed for 8 h. The solvent was removed by the water bath, and then 500 mL of water was added. The pH value of the mixture was adjusted to 1–2 with HCl (1.0 mol L–1). A pale yellow solid of H4L then was obtained. The solid product was filtered, washed by water, and dried (yield = 76%).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of H4L

A mixture of L1 (2.472 g, 3 mmol), methyl 4-(bromomethyl)benzoate (2.748 g, 12 mmol), anhydrous K2CO3 (8.28 g, 60 mmol), KI (0.1992 g, 1.2 mmol) and CH3CN (100 mL) was heated in a water bath for 12 h. Most of the solvent then was removed in the water bath. After that, tetrahydrofuran (150 mL), water (20 mL), and sodium hydroxide (0.96 g, 24 mmol) were put in the isolated products and refluxed for 8 h. The solvent was removed by the water bath, and then 500 mL of water was added. The pH value of the mixture was adjusted to 1-2 with HCl (1.0 mol L-1). A pale yellow solid of H4L then was obtained. The solid product was filtered, washed by water, and dried (yield = 76%).

elements.content: Compound 1 crystallized in the monoclinic space group Cc. As shown in Figure a, the asymmetric unit contains two Cd(II) ions, one Na(I) ion, one L anion, two coordinated HCOO– anions, one coordinated HCOOH molecule, one coordinated water, one free lattice water, and one (CH3)2NH2 + cation. The HCOOH molecule, the HCOO– anion, and the (CH3)2NH2 + cation resulted from the decomposition of the dimethylforamide (DMF) solvent, and the (CH3)2NH2 + cation balances the negative charge of the framework. Both the Cd1 and Cd2 atoms are coordinated by six oxygen atoms from two different L anions and two distinct HCOO– anions in distorted octahedral geometries. The Na1 atom also adopts a disordered octahedral geometry, coordinated by five carboxylate oxygen atoms from two distinct L anions, two different HCOO– anions and one HCOOH molecule, and one water oxygen atom. Each L anion links four Cd(II) and two Na(I) cations using four carboxylates in μ6-η1:η1:η2:η1:η1:η1:η2:η1 coordination mode (Figure b). Each HCOO– anion bridges one Cd(II) and one Na(I) cations in μ2-η1:η1 coordination mode. In these fashions, L and HCOO– anions linked Cd(II) and Na(I) atoms to generate an unusual 3D heterometallic-organic framework (Figure c), where Na(I) and Cd(II) cations are connected by carboxylate groups of L and HCOO– anions to afford an infinite Na(I)–Cd(II)-carboxylate chain. For 1, the free volume after removal of the solvent molecules is calculated by PLATON analysis to be ∼25.4%. If both Cd(II) cations and L anions are considered as 4-connected nodes, the overall framework can be simplified as a three-dimensional (3D) 4-connected framework with (42·64)(4·83·10·12) topology (Figure d).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structural Description of [(CH3)2NH2][Cd2NaL(HCOO)2(HCOOH)(H2O)]⋅H2O (1)

Compound 1 crystallized in the monoclinic space group Cc. As shown in Figure a, the asymmetric unit contains two Cd(II) ions, one Na(I) ion, one L anion, two coordinated HCOO- anions, one coordinated HCOOH molecule, one coordinated water, one free lattice water, and one (CH3)2NH2 + cation. The HCOOH molecule, the HCOO- anion, and the (CH3)2NH2 + cation resulted from the decomposition of the dimethylforamide (DMF) solvent, and the (CH3)2NH2 + cation balances the negative charge of the framework. Both the Cd1 and Cd2 atoms are coordinated by six oxygen atoms from two different L anions and two distinct HCOO- anions in distorted octahedral geometries. The Na1 atom also adopts a disordered octahedral geometry, coordinated by five carboxylate oxygen atoms from two distinct L anions, two different HCOO- anions and one HCOOH molecule, and one water oxygen atom. Each L anion links four Cd(II) and two Na(I) cations using four carboxylates in μ6-η1:η1:η2:η1:η1:η1:η2:η1 coordination mode (Figure b). Each HCOO- anion bridges one Cd(II) and one Na(I) cations in μ2-η1:η1 coordination mode. In these fashions, L and HCOO- anions linked Cd(II) and Na(I) atoms to generate an unusual 3D heterometallic-organic framework (Figure c), where Na(I) and Cd(II) cations are connected by carboxylate groups of L and HCOO- anions to afford an infinite Na(I)-Cd(II)-carboxylate chain. For 1, the free volume after removal of the solvent molecules is calculated by PLATON analysis to be ~25.4%. If both Cd(II) cations and L anions are considered as 4-connected nodes, the overall framework can be simplified as a three-dimensional (3D) 4-connected framework with (42⋅64)(4⋅83⋅10⋅12) topology (Figure d).

elements.content: During the refinement of 2, the SQUEEZE function in PLATON was applied, because of the highly disordered solvents. TGA analyses, elemental analyses, and the consideration of charge balance suggest the presence of two (CH3)2NH2 + cations, one CH3OH molecule, and four water molecules (see ). The asymmetric unit of 2 is composed of one Cd(II) cation, one L anion, two (CH3)2NH2 + cations, one CH3OH molecule, and four free waters (Figure a). Each Cd(II) atom is coordinated by four different L anions via five carboxylate oxygen atoms, displaying a disordered square-pyramid geometry. As illustrated in Figure b, each L anion connects four Cd(II) atoms using four carboxylates in μ4-η1:η0:η0:η1:η1:η1:η0:η1 fashion, yielding a 3D framework (Figure c). The (CH3)2NH2 + cations from the decomposed DMF balanced the negative charge of the framework. The calculated solvent-accessible volume in fully desolvated 2 is 33.6%, using the PLATON program. If the Cd(II) atom and L ligand are each regarded as 4-connected nodes, the entire framework can be considered as a 3D binodal 4-connected framework with (42·63·8)2 topology (Figure d).

elements.content: As shown in Figure a, the asymmetric unit consists of two Zn(II) atoms, three Na(I) atoms, two L ligands, two coordinated waters, one lattice water, and one (CH3)2NH2 + cation. Two Zn(II) atoms show distinct coordination spheres: Zn1 is surrounded by five oxygen atoms from three L ligands in a trigonal bipyramid geometry, whereas Zn2 is coordinated by four oxygen atoms from three L ligands in a tetrahedral sphere. Na(I) atoms also display different coordination spheres. Na1 is coordinated by five oxygen atoms from two L cations in a disordered trigonal bipyramid sphere, and both Na2 and Na3 are six-coordinated in disordered octahedral geomertries, surrounded by five carboxylate oxygen atoms from L cations, and one water oxygen atom. Na4 is coordinated by three carboxylate oxygen atoms from three L cations, and one water oxygen atom, exhibiting a tetrahedral geometry. Two unique L anions adopt two distinct coordination modes: one L bridges four Zn(II) and five Na(I) atoms in μ9-η1:η2:η1:η2:η2:η2:η1:η1 mode, while the other one links four Zn(II) and three Na(I) atoms in μ7-η1:η1:η1:η1:η1:η1:η1:η2 mode (Figure b). Interestingly, four Zn(II) and eight Na(I) atoms are joined together through carboxylate groups from 10 L ligands to give a rare centrosymmetric dodecanuclear heterometallic cluster (Figure c). Thereby, adjacent dodecanuclear heterometallic clusters are linked by the backbones of L anions to afford a 2D layer with unusual (3,8)-connected (3·42)(34·46·56·68·73·8) topology (Figures d and e). PLATON analysis reveals that the free void volume is ∼35.5%.

elements.content: To study the organic dye adsorption ability of 1–3, three representative organic dyes with different chargesnamely, positively charged Methylene Blue (MB), negatively charged acid orange II (AOII), and neutrally charged Sudan I (SI)were chosen in this work (see ). Typically, crystal samples of 1–3 (10 mg) were placed into a colorimeter cell containing 3 mL (5 × 10–5 mol L–1) of MB, AOII, or SI DMF solution. During a period of 48 h, the dye solutions were monitored by UV–vis absorption spectroscopy in darkness at room temperature. As illustrated in Figure , only the color of MB in DMF solution turned from blue to pale blue after 2 days. Nevertheless, the colors of AOII and SI in DMF solutions remained unchanged before and after the dye adsorption experiment (Figure ). Moreover, the concentrations of AOII and SI in DMF solutions almost remained unchanged, as shown in Figure . As a result, it can be inferred that the MB adsorption ability of compounds 1–3 is probably derived from the interaction between the negative framework and positively charged dye outside the framework. By the comparison of the pore sizes of 1–3 (see ) and the dimension of MB (4.59, 8.01, and 16.75 Å), we can infer that the positive MB cations are likely located on the sides of the pores after they exchanged the lattice positive (CH3)2NH2 + cations. Moreover, there would be strong interactions between the positively charged MB cations and the negatively charged frameworks.

Selective Adsorption of Organic Dyes in DMF Solution

To study the organic dye adsorption ability of 1-3, three representative organic dyes with different chargesnamely, positively charged Methylene Blue (MB), negatively charged acid orange II (AOII), and neutrally charged Sudan I (SI)were chosen in this work (see ). Typically, crystal samples of 1-3 (10 mg) were placed into a colorimeter cell containing 3 mL (5 × 10-5 mol L-1) of MB, AOII, or SI DMF solution. During a period of 48 h, the dye solutions were monitored by UV-vis absorption spectroscopy in darkness at room temperature. As illustrated in Figure , only the color of MB in DMF solution turned from blue to pale blue after 2 days. Nevertheless, the colors of AOII and SI in DMF solutions remained unchanged before and after the dye adsorption experiment (Figure ). Moreover, the concentrations of AOII and SI in DMF solutions almost remained unchanged, as shown in Figure . As a result, it can be inferred that the MB adsorption ability of compounds 1-3 is probably derived from the interaction between the negative framework and positively charged dye outside the framework. By the comparison of the pore sizes of 1-3 (see ) and the dimension of MB (4.59, 8.01, and 16.75 Å), we can infer that the positive MB cations are likely located on the sides of the pores after they exchanged the lattice positive (CH3)2NH2 + cations. Moreover, there would be strong interactions between the positively charged MB cations and the negatively charged frameworks.

elements.content: The quantity of adsorbed dye at the equilibrium was computed using the following formula: Q eq = ( C 0 − C eq ) V m where Q eq is the amount of MB adsorbed by 1, 2 or 3 (expressed in units of mmol g–1), C 0 is the initial concentration of MB (in mmol L–1), C eq (mmol L–1) is the concentration of MB at the equilibrium, V is the volume of MB solution (given in liters), and m is the mass of crystals that we soaked (given in grams). By calculations (see ), the values of Q eq for adsorbed MB were 0.0113, 0.0052, and 0.0102 mmol g–1 for 1, 2, and 3, respectively. The slightly different values of Q eq are primarily ascribed to their different framework structures. Noticeably, the MB adsorptivity of 1–3 is much higher than that found in compound [(CH3)2NH2]2[ZnNa2(μ2-H2O)2(H2O)2(TATAT)]·2DMF (where TATAT = 5,5′,5″-(1,3,5-triazine-2,4,6-triyl)tris(azanediyl)triisophthalate) (0.0023 mmol g–1 or 0.75 mg g–1).

elements.content: To understand the mechanism of the MB adsorption process, the crystal samples of 1, as a representive, were utilized to study the MB adsorption behaviors. For example, crystal samples of 1 (30 mg) were immersed in KI-containing DMF solution for 5 days, and then the obtained samples of 1 were filtered and dried. The ICP analysis shows that the content of K+ in the obtained samples is 0.041 mg, indicating that the (CH3)2NH2 + cations in the channels of 1 were exchanged by K+ ions. Then, 10 mg of K+-containing samples of 1 were soaked in MB-containing DMF solution for 48 h. After filtration, the ICP analysis of the filtrate exhibited that the mass of K+ is 0.0036 mg, which demonstated that K+ cations in the samples were replaced by MB cations in the DMF solution. Hence, we can conclude that the organic dye MB adsorption is an ion-exchange process. The PXRD pattern (see ) showed that the samples of 1 after exchanging with MB could keep its original framework structure.

elements.content: Recent studies have shown that I2 molecules could be introduced into CPs in iodine solution, and also could be completely released into organic solvents. Thus, the freshly prepared crystal samples of 2 (60 mg) were soaked in a cyclohexane (5 mL) solution of I2 (0.04 mol L–1). After 20 days, the color of the crystals turned from colorless to brown (Figure a). After filtration, the brown crystals were washed with a vast amount of cyclohexane until the filter liquor was colorless. As shown in Figure a, the brown crystal samples demonstrated that the I2 molecules in the cyclohexane have been adsorbed by 2. The PXRD pattern indicated that the integrity of the framework was maintained after adsorption of I2 molecules (see ). From the analysis of the pore size of 2 () and the dimensions of the I2 molecule, it can be inferred that the adsorbed I2 molecules are more likely to be accommodated into the pores of 2.

Adsorption and Release of I2 

Recent studies have shown that I2 molecules could be introduced into CPs in iodine solution, and also could be completely released into organic solvents. Thus, the freshly prepared crystal samples of 2 (60 mg) were soaked in a cyclohexane (5 mL) solution of I2 (0.04 mol L-1). After 20 days, the color of the crystals turned from colorless to brown (Figure a). After filtration, the brown crystals were washed with a vast amount of cyclohexane until the filter liquor was colorless. As shown in Figure a, the brown crystal samples demonstrated that the I2 molecules in the cyclohexane have been adsorbed by 2. The PXRD pattern indicated that the integrity of the framework was maintained after adsorption of I2 molecules (see ). From the analysis of the pore size of 2 () and the dimensions of the I2 molecule, it can be inferred that the adsorbed I2 molecules are more likely to be accommodated into the pores of 2.

elements.content: After the brown crystals of I2@2 were immersed in methanol, the color of the methanol solution changed from colorless to yellow, and the crystals became colorless (see Figures a and b). In order to understand the kinetics of I2 release for I2@2, its UV-vis spectra were recorded at room temperature. Crystal samples of I2@2 (1 mg) were soaked in a colorimeter cell with 3 mL of methanol. As illustrated in Figure c, the release rate of I2 molecules became slower, because the concentration of I2 in methanol solution increased as the time increased. The photographs and UV-vis spectra for I2@2 proved that the I2 sorption process of 2 is reversible. On the basis of a linear relationship, 0.085 mg of I2 was released from crystals of I2@1 after 30 min (see ). By calculation, 0.55 I2 molecule was accommodated in the unit cell of 2, which is slightly lower than that found in the reported porous compound [Cd(L)2(ClO4)2]·H2O (where L = 4-amino-3,5-bis(4-pyridyl-3-phenyl)-1,2,4-triazole) (0.8 I2 molecule per unit cell).

elements.content: Very recently, metal-ion exchange as a feasible method for the functional modification of CPs has undergone a rapid development. For the sake of probability of metal-ion exchange, crystal samples of 1 and 2 were each soaked in DMF solutions of MCl2 (M = Cu2+, Co2+, Ni2+) for 25 days. During this period, their Cu2+-exchanged crystals gradually turned green and Co2+-exchanged crystals became purple to the naked eye (see Figure ), but their crystals immersed in DMF solution of Ni2+ did not exhibit any change in colors. The PXRD patterns indicated that Cu2+-exchanged frameworks of 1 and 2 were in accordance with their parent structures within 216 and 168 h, respectively (see ). The PXRD patterns of Co2+-exchanged 1 and 2 also correspond to those of their parent frameworks within 600 and 216 h, respectively (see ). However, when we prolonged the soaking time, their crystals would lose their original crystallinities. The detailed exchange process of metal ions was monitored by ICP. As shown in Figure , the Cu2+ contents increased to 55.5% and 55.1% for 1 and 2 after 216 and 168 h, respectively. Correspondingly, 66.6% and 29.3% of Cd2+ in the frameworks of 1 and 2 were exchanged by Co2+ after 600 and 216 h, respectively. From the experimental results, we can see that Cd2+ ions in the frameworks are easier to be replaced by Cu2+ ions, compared with Co2+ ions, which suggests the Cu-based framework is of relatively high stability involving the Jahn–Teller effect of Cu2+.

For the sake of probability of metal-ion exchange, crystal samples of 1 and 2 were each soaked in DMF solutions of MCl2 (M = Cu2+, Co2+, Ni2+) for 25 days. During this period, their Cu2+-exchanged crystals gradually turned green and Co2+-exchanged crystals became purple to the naked eye (see Figure ), but their crystals immersed in DMF solution of Ni2+ did not exhibit any change in colors. The PXRD patterns indicated that Cu2+-exchanged frameworks of 1 and 2 were in accordance with their parent structures within 216 and 168 h, respectively (see ). The PXRD patterns of Co2+-exchanged 1 and 2 also correspond to those of their parent frameworks within 600 and 216 h, respectively (see ). However, when we prolonged the soaking time, their crystals would lose their original crystallinities. The detailed exchange process of metal ions was monitored by ICP. As shown in Figure , the Cu2+ contents increased to 55.5% and 55.1% for 1 and 2 after 216 and 168 h, respectively. Correspondingly, 66.6% and 29.3% of Cd2+ in the frameworks of 1 and 2 were exchanged by Co2+ after 600 and 216 h, respectively. From the experimental results, we can see that Cd2+ ions in the frameworks are easier to be replaced by Cu2+ ions, compared with Co2+ ions, which suggests the Cu-based framework is of relatively high stability involving the Jahn-Teller effect of Cu2+.

elements.content: Luminesent properties of CPs containing cadmium or zinc atoms have attracted much attention, because of their potential applications in electroluminescent display, chemical sensors, probes in biomedical assays, and so on. Therefore, solid-state luminescent studies were conducted for H4L and compounds 1–3 at room temperature (Figure ). For H4L ligand, the main emission peak at 494 nm (λex = 360 nm) corresponds to π* → π or π* → n transitions. The emission peaks for 1–3 are 427 (λex = 320 nm), 408 (λex = 320 nm), and 454 nm (λex = 384 nm), respectively. Relative to H4L ligand, the emission peaks for 1–3 are blue-shifted by 67, 86, and 40 nm, respectively. It can be inferred that the blue shifts are probably derived from the coordination effects of the H4L ligand to the metal cations, which not only increase the rigidity of the framework, but also reduce the loss of energy via nonradiation decay.

elements.content: As shown in Figure , the luminescent decay curve of H4L ligand at room temperature fits well into a double-exponential function as I = A + B 1 exp ( − t τ 1 ) + B 2 exp ( − t τ 2 ) The emission decay lifetime of H4L ligand is τ1 = 1.92 ns (29.93%) and τ2 = 18.05 ns (70.07%) (χ2 = 1.015). For 1–3, the luminescent decay curves agree with the three-exponential function I = A + B 1 exp ( − t τ 1 ) + B 2 exp ( − t τ 2 ) + B 3 exp ( − t τ 3 ) The emission decay lifetimes are τ1 = 0.27 ns (40.00%), τ2 = 1.55 ns (39.57%), and τ3 = 5.25 ns (20.43%) (χ2 = 0.968) for 1, τ1 = 0.37 ns (67.80%), τ2 = 1.65 ns (21.20%), and τ3 = 5.79 ns (11.00%) (χ2 = 0.964) for 2, and τ1 = 0.31 ns (54.04%), τ2 = 2.51 ns (28.37%), and τ3 = 6.35 ns (17.59%) (χ2 = 1.010) for 3. The emissions of H4L ligand and 1–3 may arise from a singlet state, because their luminescent lifetimes are much shorter than those from a triplet state.

elements.content: Recently, the highly efficient small-molecule sensing properties involving CPs have attracted considerable attention. To explore the potential of 1–3 toward the sensing of small molecules, their luminescent properties were investigated in different solvent suspensions. Solvent suspensions with 1, 2, and 3 were prepared by placing their powder samples (3 mg) into 3 mL of DMF, THF, m-xylene, benzonitrile, acetonitrile, ethanol, acetone, and nitrobenzene, respectively. Each suspension then was sonicated for 30 min before emission measurement. As shown in Figure , the emission intensities of the solvent suspensions with 1, 2, and 3 are mainly dependent on the solvents. Their emissions show different levels of quenching effects in different solvents, especially for nitrobenzene. In the nitrobenzene solvents, the emission intensities of 1–3 decrease significantly, relative to other solvents used in this study (see Figure ). The results indicate that compounds 1–3 can be used as luminescent probes for selectively detecting nitrobenzene molecules. The different degrees of quenching effects can be ascribed to the different interaction forces between solvents and frameworks of 1–3, which influenced the electron transfer process.

elements.content: Based on a new resorcin[4]arene-functionalized tetracarboxylate, three new coordination polymers (CPs) have been successfully synthesized and structurally characterized. The series of CPs display fascinating two-dimensional (2D) and three-dimensional (3D) network structures with different topologies. The result shows that H4L is a good ligand for constructing CPs with varying topological structures and properties. Remarkably, CPs 1 and 2 exhibit metal-ion exchange properties from their main frameworks, maintaining the integrity of their frameworks. CPs 1–3 display remarkable capability for selective adsorption toward the organic dye Methylene Blue (MB). CP 2 reveals outstanding performance in the reversible adsorption of iodine molecules. Furthermore, the luminescent sensing studies indicate that 1–3 are good candidates for detecting nitrobenzene molecule. It is anticipated that other novel CPs constructed by related functionalized resorcin[4]arene ligands with charming structures and excellent properties will be synthesized.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

Based on a new resorcin[4]arene-functionalized tetracarboxylate, three new coordination polymers (CPs) have been successfully synthesized and structurally characterized. The series of CPs display fascinating two-dimensional (2D) and three-dimensional (3D) network structures with different topologies. The result shows that H4L is a good ligand for constructing CPs with varying topological structures and properties. Remarkably, CPs 1 and 2 exhibit metal-ion exchange properties from their main frameworks, maintaining the integrity of their frameworks. CPs 1-3 display remarkable capability for selective adsorption toward the organic dye Methylene Blue (MB). CP 2 reveals outstanding performance in the reversible adsorption of iodine molecules. Furthermore, the luminescent sensing studies indicate that 1-3 are good candidates for detecting nitrobenzene molecule. It is anticipated that other novel CPs constructed by related functionalized resorcin[4]arene ligands with charming structures and excellent properties will be synthesized.

A mixture of 3-methoxyphenol (9.93 g, 80 mmol), hexaaldehyde (8.01 g, 80 mmol), and dichloromethane (200 mL) was stirred at ice bath for 0.5 h with the dropwise addition of BF3·OEt2 (22.7 g, 160 mmol). The reaction system was warmed to room temperature and stirred overnight. The product then was washed using water and NaOH (1 mol L–1). After drying (MgSO4) and evaporation of the solvent, the crude product was crystallized from CH2Cl2/petroleum ether and then white crystals were obtained (yield = 85%).

Synthesis of H<sub>4</sub>L

A mixture of L1 (2.472 g, 3 mmol), methyl 4-(bromomethyl)benzoate (2.748 g, 12 mmol), anhydrous K2CO3 (8.28 g, 60 mmol), KI (0.1992 g, 1.2 mmol) and CH3CN (100 mL) was heated in a water bath for 12 h. Most of the solvent then was removed in the water bath. After that, tetrahydrofuran (150 mL), water (20 mL), and sodium hydroxide (0.96 g, 24 mmol) were put in the isolated products and refluxed for 8 h. The solvent was removed by the water bath, and then 500 mL of water was added. The pH value of the mixture was adjusted to 1–2 with HCl (1.0 mol L–1). A pale yellow solid of H4L then was obtained. The solid product was filtered, washed by water, and dried (yield = 76%).

cln_elements.content:
Compound 1 crystallized in the monoclinic space group Cc. As shown in Figure a, the asymmetric unit contains two Cd(II) ions, one Na(I) ion, one L anion, two coordinated HCOO– anions, one coordinated HCOOH molecule, one coordinated water, one free lattice water, and one (CH3)2NH2 + cation. The HCOOH molecule, the HCOO– anion, and the (CH3)2NH2 + cation resulted from the decomposition of the dimethylforamide (DMF) solvent, and the (CH3)2NH2 + cation balances the negative charge of the framework. Both the Cd1 and Cd2 atoms are coordinated by six oxygen atoms from two different L anions and two distinct HCOO– anions in distorted octahedral geometries. The Na1 atom also adopts a disordered octahedral geometry, coordinated by five carboxylate oxygen atoms from two distinct L anions, two different HCOO– anions and one HCOOH molecule, and one water oxygen atom. Each L anion links four Cd(II) and two Na(I) cations using four carboxylates in μ6-η1:η1:η2:η1:η1:η1:η2:η1 coordination mode (Figure b). Each HCOO– anion bridges one Cd(II) and one Na(I) cations in μ2-η1:η1 coordination mode. In these fashions, L and HCOO– anions linked Cd(II) and Na(I) atoms to generate an unusual 3D heterometallic-organic framework (Figure c), where Na(I) and Cd(II) cations are connected by carboxylate groups of L and HCOO– anions to afford an infinite Na(I)–Cd(II)-carboxylate chain. For 1, the free volume after removal of the solvent molecules is calculated by PLATON analysis to be ∼25.4%. If both Cd(II) cations and L anions are considered as 4-connected nodes, the overall framework can be simplified as a three-dimensional (3D) 4-connected framework with (42·64)(4·83·10·12) topology (Figure d).

Structural Description of [(CH<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>NH<sub>2</sub>]<sub>2</sub>[CdL]·4H<sub>2</sub>O·CH<sub>3</sub>OH (<bold>2</bold>)

During the refinement of 2, the SQUEEZE function in PLATON was applied, because of the highly disordered solvents. TGA analyses, elemental analyses, and the consideration of charge balance suggest the presence of two (CH3)2NH2 + cations, one CH3OH molecule, and four water molecules (see ). The asymmetric unit of 2 is composed of one Cd(II) cation, one L anion, two (CH3)2NH2 + cations, one CH3OH molecule, and four free waters (Figure a). Each Cd(II) atom is coordinated by four different L anions via five carboxylate oxygen atoms, displaying a disordered square-pyramid geometry. As illustrated in Figure b, each L anion connects four Cd(II) atoms using four carboxylates in μ4-η1:η0:η0:η1:η1:η1:η0:η1 fashion, yielding a 3D framework (Figure c). The (CH3)2NH2 + cations from the decomposed DMF balanced the negative charge of the framework. The calculated solvent-accessible volume in fully desolvated 2 is 33.6%, using the PLATON program. If the Cd(II) atom and L ligand are each regarded as 4-connected nodes, the entire framework can be considered as a 3D binodal 4-connected framework with (42·63·8)2 topology (Figure d).

Luminescent Properties

Luminesent properties of CPs containing cadmium or zinc atoms have attracted much attention, because of their potential applications in electroluminescent display, chemical sensors, probes in biomedical assays, and so on. Therefore, solid-state luminescent studies were conducted for H4L and compounds 1–3 at room temperature (Figure ). For H4L ligand, the main emission peak at 494 nm (λex = 360 nm) corresponds to π* → π or π* → n transitions. The emission peaks for 1–3 are 427 (λex = 320 nm), 408 (λex = 320 nm), and 454 nm (λex = 384 nm), respectively. Relative to H4L ligand, the emission peaks for 1–3 are blue-shifted by 67, 86, and 40 nm, respectively. It can be inferred that the blue shifts are probably derived from the coordination effects of the H4L ligand to the metal cations, which not only increase the rigidity of the framework, but also reduce the loss of energy via nonradiation decay.

Results and Discussion

Structural Description of [(CH3)2NH2][Cd2NaL(HCOO)2(HCOOH)(H2O)]⋅H2O (1)

Compound 1 crystallized in the monoclinic space group Cc. As shown in Figure a, the asymmetric unit contains two Cd(II) ions, one Na(I) ion, one L anion, two coordinated HCOO- anions, one coordinated HCOOH molecule, one coordinated water, one free lattice water, and one (CH3)2NH2 + cation. The HCOOH molecule, the HCOO- anion, and the (CH3)2NH2 + cation resulted from the decomposition of the dimethylforamide (DMF) solvent, and the (CH3)2NH2 + cation balances the negative charge of the framework. Both the Cd1 and Cd2 atoms are coordinated by six oxygen atoms from two different L anions and two distinct HCOO- anions in distorted octahedral geometries. The Na1 atom also adopts a disordered octahedral geometry, coordinated by five carboxylate oxygen atoms from two distinct L anions, two different HCOO- anions and one HCOOH molecule, and one water oxygen atom. Each L anion links four Cd(II) and two Na(I) cations using four carboxylates in μ6-η1:η1:η2:η1:η1:η1:η2:η1 coordination mode (Figure b). Each HCOO- anion bridges one Cd(II) and one Na(I) cations in μ2-η1:η1 coordination mode. In these fashions, L and HCOO- anions linked Cd(II) and Na(I) atoms to generate an unusual 3D heterometallic-organic framework (Figure c), where Na(I) and Cd(II) cations are connected by carboxylate groups of L and HCOO- anions to afford an infinite Na(I)-Cd(II)-carboxylate chain. For 1, the free volume after removal of the solvent molecules is calculated by PLATON analysis to be ~25.4%. If both Cd(II) cations and L anions are considered as 4-connected nodes, the overall framework can be simplified as a three-dimensional (3D) 4-connected framework with (42⋅64)(4⋅83⋅10⋅12) topology (Figure d).

Structural Description of [(CH3)2NH2]2[CdL]⋅4H2O⋅CH3OH (2)

During the refinement of 2, the SQUEEZE function in PLATON was applied, because of the highly disordered solvents. TGA analyses, elemental analyses, and the consideration of charge balance suggest the presence of two (CH3)2NH2 + cations, one CH3OH molecule, and four water molecules (see ). The asymmetric unit of 2 is composed of one Cd(II) cation, one L anion, two (CH3)2NH2 + cations, one CH3OH molecule, and four free waters (Figure a). Each Cd(II) atom is coordinated by four different L anions via five carboxylate oxygen atoms, displaying a disordered square-pyramid geometry. As illustrated in Figure b, each L anion connects four Cd(II) atoms using four carboxylates in μ4-η1:η0:η0:η1:η1:η1:η0:η1 fashion, yielding a 3D framework (Figure c). The (CH3)2NH2 + cations from the decomposed DMF balanced the negative charge of the framework. The calculated solvent-accessible volume in fully desolvated 2 is 33.6%, using the PLATON program. If the Cd(II) atom and L ligand are each regarded as 4-connected nodes, the entire framework can be considered as a 3D binodal 4-connected framework with (42⋅63⋅8)2 topology (Figure d).

Luminescent Properties

Luminesent properties of CPs containing cadmium or zinc atoms have attracted much attention, because of their potential applications in electroluminescent display, chemical sensors, probes in biomedical assays, and so on. Therefore, solid-state luminescent studies were conducted for H4L and compounds 1-3 at room temperature (Figure ). For H4L ligand, the main emission peak at 494 nm (λex = 360 nm) corresponds to π* → π or π* → n transitions. The emission peaks for 1-3 are 427 (λex = 320 nm), 408 (λex = 320 nm), and 454 nm (λex = 384 nm), respectively. Relative to H4L ligand, the emission peaks for 1-3 are blue-shifted by 67, 86, and 40 nm, respectively. It can be inferred that the blue shifts are probably derived from the coordination effects of the H4L ligand to the metal cations, which not only increase the rigidity of the framework, but also reduce the loss of energy via nonradiation decay.
